expanded_description: SI base units are the fundamental building blocks of the International System of Units. These seven independent units form the foundation from which all other measurements in physics are derived.

core_concept.principle: The SI system is built on seven base units that measure fundamental physical quantities. All other units are derived from combinations of these base units.
core_concept.explanation: Base units are defined independently using physical constants or natural phenomena. They are the foundation of the metric system—every measurement in physics can be expressed using these seven units or combinations of them. Understanding base units is essential because they appear in every physics formula and calculation.

image.caption: The seven SI base units form the foundation of all scientific measurement

sections.introduction: Not all units are created equal. Some units are fundamental—defined independently and used to build all other units. These are the base units.

key_concept.definition: SI base units are seven fundamental units of measurement that are defined independently and cannot be expressed as combinations of other units. They measure the most basic physical quantities.
key_concept.context: Every measurement in physics ultimately traces back to these seven base units. For example, speed (m/s) uses the meter and second; force (kg·m/s²) uses kilogram, meter, and second; energy (kg·m²/s²) also combines base units.

principles.statement: Base units are defined independently—they don't depend on other units for their definition.
principles.application: Each base unit has its own standard definition based on physical constants or phenomena.
principles.example: The meter is defined using the speed of light, not by relating it to other units. The second is defined by atomic oscillations.

principles.statement: The seven base units are sufficient to express any physical quantity.
principles.application: All other units (derived units) can be created by combining base units.
principles.example: Velocity = distance/time = meters/seconds = m/s (combines meter and second). Force = mass × acceleration = kg × m/s² (combines kilogram, meter, and second).

principles.statement: Base units have precise, internationally agreed-upon definitions.
principles.application: Scientists anywhere in the world can reproduce these standards with extreme precision.
principles.example: The second is defined as exactly 9,192,631,770 oscillations of cesium-133 atoms—the same everywhere.

image.alt: Diagram showing base units at the foundation with derived units built from them
image.caption: Base units are the building blocks; derived units are combinations of base units

sections.introduction: The International System of Units defines exactly seven base units. Each measures a fundamental physical quantity that cannot be expressed in terms of other quantities.

key_concept.definition: The seven SI base units are: meter (length), kilogram (mass), second (time), ampere (electric current), kelvin (temperature), mole (amount of substance), and candela (luminous intensity).
key_concept.context: For Grade 9/10 physics, you'll work primarily with the first five. Mole is used in chemistry, and candela in specialized lighting applications.

classifications.value: Measures distance, length, width, height, or displacement
characteristics: Base unit for all distance measurements
classifications.behavior: Describes how far apart objects are or how long something is in space.

examples.explanation: Height of a person (1.7 m), length of a room (5 m), distance to school (2000 m or 2 km).
Displacement in motion equations, wavelength of light, radius of a circle.

image.alt: Illustration showing the meter defined by light travel distance
image.caption: The meter is defined as the distance light travels in 1/299,792,458 of a second in vacuum

classifications.note: Originally defined as one ten-millionth of the distance from equator to North Pole. Now defined using the speed of light for extreme precision.

classifications.value: Measures the amount of matter in an object
characteristics: Only base unit with a prefix (kilo-) in its name
Base unit for inertia and gravitational attraction
classifications.behavior: Describes how much matter an object contains—its resistance to acceleration.

examples.explanation: Mass of a student (50 kg), a textbook (1 kg), a car (1200 kg).
F = ma (force depends on mass), gravitational force calculations, momentum (p = mv).

image.alt: Diagram showing kilogram definition using Planck constant
image.caption: The kilogram is now defined using the Planck constant, a fundamental constant of nature

classifications.note: Until 2019, the kilogram was defined by a physical platinum-iridium cylinder in France. Now defined using the Planck constant for reproducibility anywhere.

classifications.value: Measures duration or the interval between events
characteristics: Base unit for all timing and frequency measurements
classifications.behavior: Describes how long something takes or when events occur relative to each other.

examples.explanation: Time for a ball to fall (2 s), class period (3000 s or 50 min), reaction time (0.2 s).
Velocity = distance/time, acceleration = change in velocity/time, period of oscillation.

image.alt: Illustration of cesium atom oscillations defining the second
image.caption: One second is defined as 9,192,631,770 periods of cesium-133 atomic radiation

classifications.note: Atomic clocks using cesium-133 are so precise they would lose less than 1 second in 100 million years.

classifications.value: Measures the flow rate of electric charge
characteristics: Base unit for all electrical measurements
classifications.behavior: Describes how much electric charge flows past a point per second.

examples.explanation: Current through a light bulb (0.5 A), phone charger (1-2 A), household circuit (15-20 A maximum).
Ohm's Law: V = IR (voltage = current × resistance), P = IV (power = current × voltage).

image.alt: Diagram showing electric current and the ampere
image.caption: The ampere is defined using the elementary charge (charge of one electron)

classifications.note: One ampere means one coulomb of charge flowing past a point each second. Important in electricity and magnetism topics.

characteristics: Absolute scale starting at absolute zero (0 K)
Base unit for all temperature measurements
classifications.behavior: Describes the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance.

examples.explanation: Water freezes at 273.15 K (0°C), boils at 373.15 K (100°C). Room temperature ≈ 293 K (20°C).
Gas laws (PV = nRT), thermal expansion, heat transfer calculations.

image.alt: Comparison of Kelvin and Celsius temperature scales
image.caption: Kelvin scale starts at absolute zero; one kelvin equals one degree Celsius in size

classifications.note: 0 K (absolute zero) is -273.15°C, the lowest possible temperature. Kelvin and Celsius have the same size degree, just different zero points: K = °C + 273.15

classifications.value: Measures the number of elementary entities (atoms, molecules, etc.)
classifications.behavior: Describes how many atoms, molecules, or other particles are present.

examples.explanation: 1 mole of carbon atoms = 6.022 × 10²³ atoms = 12 g of carbon. 1 mole of water molecules = 6.022 × 10²³ molecules = 18 g.
Chemical reaction stoichiometry, ideal gas law (PV = nRT where n is moles).

classifications.note: Less commonly used in Grade 9/10 physics, but essential in chemistry. Connects atomic-scale particles to measurable quantities.

classifications.value: Measures the intensity of light in a given direction
characteristics: Measures perceived brightness by human eye
classifications.behavior: Describes how bright a light source appears in a particular direction.

examples.explanation: Typical candle ≈ 1 cd, flashlight ≈ 20-30 cd, car headlight ≈ 10,000-20,000 cd.

classifications.note: Rarely used in basic physics courses. Most relevant in advanced optics and lighting engineering.

principles.statement: The five base units you'll use most are: meter, kilogram, second, ampere, and kelvin.
principles.application: These appear in virtually every physics topic: mechanics, energy, electricity, and heat.
principles.example: Velocity (m/s), force (kg·m/s²), energy (kg·m²/s²), power (kg·m²/s³), current (A), resistance (kg·m²/(A²·s³)).

principles.statement: These seven quantities are independent—none can be expressed in terms of the others.
principles.application: You cannot define mass using length and time, or temperature using mass and length—they're fundamentally different.
principles.example: Length and time can be combined to make speed (m/s), but speed is not a base unit—it's derived from base units.

image.alt: Table summarizing all seven SI base units with symbols and quantities
image.caption: The seven SI base units: the foundation of all scientific measurement

sections.introduction: Modern SI base units are defined using fundamental constants of nature rather than physical objects. This ensures they can be reproduced anywhere with high precision.

key_concept.definition: SI base units are now defined using fixed values of fundamental physical constants, making them reproducible in any laboratory with appropriate equipment.
key_concept.context: This 2019 redefinition replaced artifact-based definitions (like the platinum kilogram) with constant-based definitions for ultimate precision and accessibility.

categories.description: Base units are defined by fixing exact numerical values for fundamental constants of physics.

examples.explanation: The speed of light in vacuum is defined as exactly 299,792,458 m/s. The meter is then the distance light travels in 1/299,792,458 second.
The second is defined by exactly 9,192,631,770 oscillations of cesium-133 atoms under specific conditions.
The Planck constant is fixed at exactly 6.62607015 × 10⁻³⁴ kg·m²/s. The kilogram is derived from this value.
The charge of one electron is fixed at exactly 1.602176634 × 10⁻¹⁹ coulombs. The ampere follows from this.

categories.description: Constant-based definitions ensure measurements can be reproduced anywhere.

examples.explanation: Any country with an atomic clock can realize the second. No need to compare to a reference object in France.
Physical constants are truly constant everywhere in the universe, unlike manufactured objects which can degrade.
Tying units to fundamental physics connects measurement to the deepest laws of nature.

image.alt: Diagram showing fundamental constants used to define SI base units
image.caption: Modern SI definitions use fundamental constants for precision and reproducibility

sections.introduction: Understanding base units helps you work with formulas, check calculations, and understand what different measurements mean.

principles.statement: Every physics formula ultimately uses combinations of base units.
principles.application: Understanding this helps you remember formulas and check if your calculations make sense.
principles.example: Force: F = ma. Mass is in kg, acceleration is in m/s². So force is in kg·m/s², which we call the Newton (N).

principles.statement: Checking that both sides of an equation have the same base unit combination reveals errors.
principles.application: If units don't match, you've made a mistake.
principles.example: If you calculate a distance and get kg·s instead of m, something went wrong—distance must have dimension [L].

principles.statement: Metric prefixes can be added to base units to express different scales.
principles.application: Makes measurements convenient—neither too large nor too small numbers.
principles.example: Meter: km (1000 m), cm (0.01 m), mm (0.001 m), μm (10⁻⁶ m), nm (10⁻⁹ m). Kilogram: g (0.001 kg), mg (10⁻⁶ kg). Second: ms (0.001 s), μs (10⁻⁶ s).

worked_examples.title: Identifying Base Units in Measurements
worked_examples.problem: Identify which SI base unit(s) are involved in measuring: (a) how fast a car is moving, (b) how much force you exert pushing a box, (c) the energy in a battery.

step_by_step.explanation: Speed = distance/time. Uses meter (length) and second (time). Units: m/s.
Force = mass × acceleration. Mass in kg, acceleration in m/s². Uses kilogram, meter, and second. Units: kg·m/s².
Energy has units of force × distance = (kg·m/s²) × m = kg·m²/s². Uses kilogram, meter, and second.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) meter and second, (b) kilogram, meter, and second, (c) kilogram, meter, and second
worked_examples.concept_applied: All physics measurements trace back to combinations of SI base units.

worked_examples.title: Working with Base Units
worked_examples.problem: A car has a mass of 1200 kg and accelerates at 2.5 m/s². What base units are involved in calculating the force?

step_by_step.explanation: Acceleration = 2.5 m/s². This uses: meter (for distance) and second (for time)
F = ma = kg × (m/s²) = kg·m/s². Uses three base units: kilogram, meter, second

step_by_step.calculation: The Newton (N) is the derived unit for force, equal to kg·m/s²

worked_examples.final_answer: Force uses three base units: kilogram (mass), meter (length), and second (time). F = 3000 kg·m/s² or 3000 N.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Derived quantities like force are built from combinations of base units.

worked_examples.title: Converting with Base Units
worked_examples.problem: Express these quantities using only SI base units (no prefixes): (a) 5.2 km, (b) 750 g, (c) 45 ms
worked_examples.concept_applied: SI base units are meter (not kilometer), kilogram (not gram), and second (not millisecond). Calculations are often easiest when using base units.

sections.introduction: Understanding the distinction between base and derived units clarifies the structure of the SI system.

key_concept.definition: Base units are defined independently and measure fundamental quantities. Derived units are combinations of base units and measure quantities defined by relationships between base quantities.
key_concept.context: All units are either base units or derived from base units through multiplication, division, or powers.

characteristics: Cannot be expressed using other units
Form the foundation of the SI system
Defined by fundamental constants or phenomena
classifications.behavior: Stand alone—don't depend on other units for definition.

examples.explanation: meter (m), kilogram (kg), second (s), ampere (A), kelvin (K), mole (mol), candela (cd)

classifications.value: Built from combinations of base units
characteristics: Expressed as products, quotients, or powers of base units
Can have special names (Newton, Joule) or just be written as combinations
classifications.behavior: Depend on base units—defined by combining base units according to physical laws.

examples.explanation: Area (m²), volume (m³), speed (m/s), acceleration (m/s²), density (kg/m³)
Newton (kg·m/s²) for force, Joule (kg·m²/s²) for energy, Watt (kg·m²/s³) for power, Volt (kg·m²/(A·s³)) for voltage

principles.principle: Every Unit Traces to Base Units
principles.statement: No matter how complex, every SI unit can be broken down into base units.
principles.application: This provides a universal foundation for all measurements.
principles.example: Pressure (Pascal) = force/area = (kg·m/s²)/m² = kg/(m·s²). Even complex units reduce to base units.

image.alt: Diagram showing how derived units are built from base units
image.caption: Derived units are combinations of the seven base units

sections.introduction: Understanding base units isn't just academic—it's practical for problem-solving, communication, and scientific thinking.

categories.description: Base units provide a common language for scientists worldwide.

examples.explanation: When scientists in different countries share data, using SI base units ensures everyone understands exactly what was measured.

categories.description: Base units help check if equations and calculations are correct.

examples.explanation: If you calculate distance and get kg·s instead of m, you know there's a mistake—the dimensions don't match.

categories.description: Seeing how quantities relate through base units reveals connections.

examples.explanation: Force (kg·m/s²) × distance (m) = energy (kg·m²/s²). The base unit structure shows the relationship.

categories.description: Understanding base units makes learning new physics concepts easier.

examples.explanation: When you learn about momentum (kg·m/s), power (kg·m²/s³), or magnetic flux (kg·m²/(A·s²)), knowing they're built from base units helps you understand them.

summary: The SI system is built on seven base units that measure fundamental physical quantities: meter (m) for length, kilogram (kg) for mass, second (s) for time, ampere (A) for electric current, kelvin (K) for temperature, mole (mol) for amount of substance, and candela (cd) for luminous intensity. These units are defined independently using fundamental constants of nature, making them reproducible anywhere with precision. In Grade 9/10 physics, you'll work primarily with meter, kilogram, second, ampere, and kelvin. Base units are the building blocks—all other measurements (derived units) are combinations of these seven through multiplication, division, or powers. For example, speed (m/s) combines meter and second; force (kg·m/s²) combines kilogram, meter, and second. Understanding base units is essential for dimensional analysis, error checking, unit conversion, and comprehending physical relationships. Every physics formula ultimately expresses relationships between these fundamental quantities, making base units the foundation of all scientific measurement.
